title: Chimpanzees and Alcohol: Testing the Drunken Monkey Hypothesis
summary: A recent study published in Biology Letters provides strong evidence for the "drunken monkey hypothesis," a theory proposed by biologist Robert Dudley. Researchers investigated whether chimpanzees consume alcohol by analyzing their urine for alcohol metabolites. Graduate students, including Aleksey Maro, collected urine samples from chimps in Africa using innovative methods like plastic bags hung on twigs. They tested the samples with immunoassay strips and found that 16 out of 20 samples contained ethyl glucuronide, an alcohol byproduct, at levels equivalent to one or two human drinks. This indicates that chimps regularly eat fermented fruit, which contains ethanol, supporting the idea that human attraction to alcohol may have evolutionary roots dating back millions of years. The study also noted that females in estrus and juveniles had lower alcohol levels, suggesting future research directions. While this adds to previous observations of chimps sharing alcoholic fruit, gaps remain, such as proving chimps selectively choose high-ethanol fruits. Overall, the research connects food and alcohol in primate evolution, highlighting the role of fermented resources in animal diets.

background_read: The drunken monkey hypothesis, introduced by Robert Dudley in 2014, argues that human affinity for alcohol stems from ancestral primates eating fermented fruit. This theory challenges earlier skepticism that primates avoid such foods. Recent studies, including camera footage of chimps sharing alcoholic breadfruit and measurements of fruit ethanol content, have built evidence. Alcohol metabolites like ethyl glucuronide are used in human tests to detect drinking, and similar methods were adapted for chimps. Evolutionary biology explores how traits develop over time, and this research connects primate diets to human behaviors, offering insights into addiction and social habits. Understanding animal consumption of fermented resources can inform conservation and health studies.
